sentence: Stocks have quietly drifted into the red ahead of the release of minutes from the latest Federal Open Market Committee meeting later this afternoon.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 were marginally lower, weighed down by losses for the financial and consumer discretionary sectors although a rebound for semiconductor stocks was carrying the Nasdaq Composite index to a narrow advance.

Without any economic data to digest this morning, U.S. equities settled into a holding pattern just below yesterday's record levels while most European bourses were lower following profit-taking from Tuesday's ECB-fueled gains, Trading has turned slightly negative since the opening bell although losses are mitigated by the expectations the Fed remained bullish on the U.S. economy while at the same time taking a June rate hike off the table.
In corporate news, the Department of Justice along with state and other government regulators have fined six of the largest banks more than $5 billion for foreign exchange manipulation.
As a result, JP Morgan ( JPM ) and Citigroup ( C ) have both slipped into negative territory.
Home-improvement retailer Lowe's ( LOW ) reported disappointing Q1 results a day after competitor Home Depot ( HD ) beat Q1 estimates and raised EPS outlook.
Johnson and Johnson said its Janssen Pharmaceutical unit plans to file regulatory approval for 10 new drugs by 2019, each with the potential to earn more than $1 billion.
Also, Target ( TGT ) reported upbeat Q1 earnings and raised its FY15 earnings outlook.
Crude oil was up 88 cents to $58.86 per barrel.
Natural gas was up 3 cents to $3.03 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was up $2.90 to $1,208.60 an ounce, while silver was up 9 cents to $17.17 an ounce.
Copper was unchanged at $2.83 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was up 1.27% to $19.88 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was up 0.48% to $14.69.
Amongst precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was unchanged at 22.18 while SPDR Gold Shares were up 0.15% to $116.05.
The iShares Silver Trust was up 0.34% to $16.44.

Here's where U.S. stocks stand at mid-day:

(+) SRPT (+53.66%) Plans to submit rolling NDA for Eteplirsen after meeting with FDA

(+) PBY (+14.49%) Acquisition interest from Golden Gate Capital and others

(-) LPTN (-79.85%) Due to disappointing results from a clinical trial for chronic eye disease the company will conserve cash by restructuring its workforce.

(-) ETSY (-22.05%) Posts worse-than-expected Q1 loss and revenue in line with forecasts

(-) ACHN (-13.63%) Collaborating with Johnson and Johnson (JNJ) unit on hepatitis C treatment; downgraded at UBS to neutral from buy
